statement:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring and let $R[X]$ be the ring of polynomials
with coefficients in $R$.

Let $S$ be a commutative ring, and let $\psi\colon R\to S$ be a
homomorphism. Further, let $s\in S$. Then there is a unique homomorphism
$\phi\colon R[X]\to S$ taking $X$ to $s$ and taking every $r\in R$ to
$\psi(r)$.

This amounts to saying that polynomial rings are free objects in the
category of $R$-algebras; the theorem then states that they are
projective. This is true in much greater generality; in fact, the
property of being projective is intended to extract the essential
property of being free.

We first prove existence. Let $f\in R[X]$. Then by definition there is
some finite list of $a_i$ such that $f = \sum_i a_i X^i$. Then define
$\phi(f)$ to be $\sum_i \psi(a_i) s^i$. It is clear from the definition
of addition and multiplication on polynomials that $\phi$ is a
homomorphism; the definition makes it clear that $\phi(X)=s$ and
$\phi(r)=\psi(r)$.

Now, to show uniqueness, suppose $\gamma$ is any homomorphism satisfying
the conditions of the theorem, and let $f\in R[X]$. Write
$f = \sum_i a_i X^i$ as before. Then $\gamma(a_i) = \psi(a_i)$ and
$\gamma(s)$ by assumption. But then since $\gamma$ is a homomorphism,
$\gamma(a_iX^i) = \psi(a_i)s^i$ and
$\gamma(f) = \sum_i \psi(a_i) s^i = \phi(f)$.
